topic.title: HPE Helion 2.0 Development Platform: PHP MySQL Database Sample

body.p: This very simple PHP web app displays the text "Executed query "SELECT "Hello World!"".", and then the result of that query "Hello World!" This is a demonstration of the minimum requirements to build an application that can connect to a MySQL database provided by ALS and run queries against it. Use this sample to ensure that you have set up your environment for connecting to and working with MySQL on the Helion Development Platform.

ul.li: An installation of the HPE Helion Development Platform.
Access to an Application Lifecycle Service (ALS) Cluster
Access to the Helion command-line client (CLI).
Access to the web-based ALS Management Console.
The MySQL service is not enabled by default. Check and make sure it is enabled.
Register for access to the HPE Helion Development Platform (HDN).

section.title: Enable the MySQL Service
section.p: If the MySQL service is not enabled on your cluster, or if you are not sure, follow these steps:

ol.li: Go to the Administrative console for your ALS cluster. For example: https://api.xx.xx.xx.xx.xip.io, substitute your own cluster's link.
On the Admin tab, click Cluster.
Click Cluster Nodes on the left side of the page.
Click the Settings icon (a gear icon in the upper right corner)
The MySQL check box should be checked. If it is not, check it.

section.p: Note: If a more durable or scalable MySQL database service is needed, configure your ALS cluster to use a database instance or master/slave pair provided by the Database Service. For more information, refer to Using the Database Service and Connecting the Database Service with ALS.

section.title: Download the Application Files
section.p: Click here to access the code repository.

Manifest.yml is a configuration file used to specify settings. For PHP only the name and buildpack fields are required. The buildpack field is a URL for the buildpack that supports the necessary language and/or framework.
This app uses the Cloud Foundry PHP buildpack. For more technical details about buildpacks and the composer.json file, please see the README included in the download package.

section.title: Deploy the Application
section.p: Application Lifecycle Service clusters that require an upstream HTTP proxy to access the internet will need to be made aware of the proxy. The sample applications require access to the Internet in order to download dependent packages.
Use the Helion client to deploy your app to Helion Development Platform. If you have Eclipse installed, you have the option to use the plugin.

ol.li: Ensure that you are targeting your desired environment. If you are not, executehelion target https://api.xx.xx.xx.xx.xip.io
Ensure that you are logged in to your desired environment. If you are not, executehelion login
If you are not already there, cd to the root directory of the sample.
Deploy the application by using the command:helion push

Accept any default values that you may be prompted for. By default ALS clusters are configured with two domains (private and public). In some situations the Helion CLI may prompt you to select a target domain. If prompted, select the public domain from the given list (i.e. <app-name>.xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx.xip.io)
Open the Helion Management Console. This is the web-based administrative interface.
If the file push was successful, you should see mysql-php in the list of available applications.

In the upper right-hand corner, click View App to see your app in action.
This app connects to the MySQL service, executes a query, and displays a page showing the retrieved text.

section.title: Key Code Snippets
section.p: This first line in this section of the index.php file shows how to retrieve the connection information for the MySQL instance from the application's environment variables. The connection information is represented using JSON.

The rest of the code shown here parses the JSON string that was retrieved and builds the appropriate connection string. Once the connection has been made, the code executes a query, reads the results, and closes the connection.

The manifest.yml file contains the configuration information used by ALS to set up the environment. The services element informs ALS on how to bind to the MySQL service provided by the ALS cluster to the application. The file also uses the buildpack element that is used by ALS to configure the application environment for using PHP.
section.codeblock: --- applications: - name: mysql-php buildpack: https://github.com/cloudfoundry/php-buildpack.git services: ${name}-db: type: mysql

section.title: Key Learnings

ul.li: ALS requires configuration information so that it can bind to a MySQL service. Configuration information is contained in the manifest.yml file.
You will need to provide information about which build pack to use for PHP so that ALS can create an environment for your app. Configuration information is contained in the manifest.yml file.
You will need to retrieve connection information for MySQL from the application's environment variables and then parse that information into a connection string that can be used by PHP.
You interact with and deploy your app using the ALS command line client or the web-based ALS Management Console.
